page.title: 01WADDINGTON-A DIVIDED VILLAGE
page.content: When many Lincolnshire people think of Waddington they think only of the village that lies on the limestone ridge to the south of Lincoln. Another major section of the parish, however, lies to the west at the foot of the ridge in the lowfields of the River Witham. This division is so marked that most people in lower Waddington consider themselves to be from Lincoln rather than from Waddington. There have been many initiatives to build closer links between the two wards, particularly by organisations in upper Waddington, but the differences persist. Lower Waddington consists mainly of modern bungalow estates with a high proportion of young families. Upper Waddington has the old stone-built village together with more recent housing and a greater proportion of retired people.
